title-group.article-title: An improved Geneva mechanism for optimal kinematic performance

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran

abstract.p: In this article, an alternative Geneva mechanism is presented and optimized. Unlike the original mechanism in which the driving pin operates at a fixed radius, the alternative mechanism benefits from a fixed groove cam which controls the radius of action of driving pin, resulting in continuous wheel acceleration and lower maximum velocity and acceleration. Apolynomial displacement function is adopted for the cam in the interval of engagement of driver and wheel. The problem of finding the coefficients of the polynomial is formulated as a constrained optimization problem in which the maximum acceleration of the Geneva wheel is to be minimized, while the motion of the pin is constrained to have zero velocity and zero acceleration at the beginning and end of the motion, respectively. Moreover, it is argued that since the objective function is highly sensitive to the variations of design variables, traditional search algorithms often fail to find its global optimum. To resolve this problem, a new hybrid genetic algorithm with a built-in adaptive local search is employed to find the coefficients of a polynomial that would define the optimal groove profile. The proposed approach is applied to the classical problems of designing a Geneva mechanism with four, five, and six grooves, and the results are compared with those obtained by other methods. The comparison shows that the proposed approach is capable of designing shock-free mechanisms with significantly reduced maximum angular velocity and acceleration of the Geneva wheel.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p:
Although a variety of alternative tools have been proposed for generating intermittent motion [1, 2], the Geneva mechanism continues to be the most widely used tool by the industry. The input motion to the mechanism is rotational and depending on the number of slots in Geneva wheel, the output motion has dwells. A typical Geneva mechanism with four slots is shown in Fig. 1. Fig. 1
Schematic view of a common Geneva mechanism (locking part of the mechanism is not shown): (a) instant of beginning (or end) of wheel motion and (b) configuration in an intermediate state

Despite their topological simplicity, traditional Geneva mechanisms suffer a number of common drawbacks. For example, once the number of dwells is selected, the designer is restricted to a given motion curve which causes the wheel to rotate with a non-smooth angular velocity and acceleration, meaning that the acceleration of the wheel is not zero at the beginning and end of its motion. This would result in an infinite jerk at these points, which makes the mechanism somewhat impractical. Moreover, the maximum value of the output angular acceleration is quite high, especially for a low number of grooves, resulting in large inertia forces during the motion.

Several suggestions have been made to resolve this problem. Using two Geneva wheels in series [3], Geneva wheels with curved slots [4–9], non-linear spring [10], and double-crank [11] are among the modifications aimed at improving the high-speed performance of the Geneva mechanism.

Recently, the notion of a variable input speed has been proposed for the modification of kinematic and dynamic characteristics of some common mechanism. This method has been applied to many high-performance mechanisms to achieve modification of kinematic and dynamic characteristics [12, 13]. Lee and Cho [14] used an optimal control method to improve the kinematic characteristics of the Geneva wheel. Instead of driving the input member at a constant speed, they used an optimal control method to find an appropriate variable velocity to modify some of the output characteristics, but this method needs a servo-motor or an extra mechanism to generate the required variable input speed.

Controlling the driving pin on the driving wheel is another strategy that has been successfully used to improve the output motion. For instance, Sujan and Meggiolaro [15] synthesized a crank-rocker four-bar linkage with a drive-pin located on a coupler point for driving a Geneva wheel. Pugh [16] and Jiguang [17] designed hypocycloid gears to replace the traditional crank of Geneva mechanisms.

Nonetheless, the alternative concept of using a customized cam to control the driving pin has not been properly explored in the literature. An optimized groove-cam has a unique capability to control kinematic characteristic of the Geneva wheel and the synthesis of the modified mechanism is not complicated in comparison to the previous methods in references [15–17].

Chironis [2] suggested a Geneva mechanism with variable radius of driving pin, as shown in Fig. 2. It comprises a groove-cam, a driving disk, a Geneva wheel, and an arm. The driving disk rotates the arm and the groove-cam makes the arm move along the radius of driving disk. This makes the tangential velocity of the driving pin vary with the rotation of the Geneva wheel. Fig. 2
The modified Geneva mechanism

The main advantage of the modified mechanism isthat the motion curves of driving wheel can be controlled by adjusting the profile of the cam. Therefore, the designer can control the motion of Geneva wheel. There are some standard profiles that can be used for cam but it will be more effective if an optimized profile is selected. In this article, genetic algorithm (GA) is applied to find the coefficients of the polynomial that is used for the profile of the cam. For this purpose, the objective function and constraints are extracted on the basis of the variable distance between the driving pin and the centre of driving disk; and then an evolutionary optimization algorithm is used to solve the constrained problem.

sec.title: 2 PROBLEM FORMULATION
sec.p: In this section, the optimization problem for the modified Geneva mechanism is formulated. Figure 1 shows the common configuration of mechanism in which the driving pin P on the input disk is at a fixed radius r1 entering (and exiting) the grooves of the Geneva wheel (output) at right angle (Fig. 1(a)). The grooves on the wheel are straight and radial, and so, the angular velocity of the wheel will be continuous starting and ending at zero.

To avoid the drawbacks of conventional Geneva mechanism, a number of modifications have been proposed, including the use of wheels with specially designed curved grooves [4–9]. It could be argued that although a curved groove often results in improved performance, it introduces such disadvantages as uncertainty of motion due to the presence of a change point, stricter manufacturing, and assembly accuracy demands and higher shock loads in the presence of clearance in the mechanism [18]. To avoid these disadvantages, in this study, the original wheel shape is preserved.

To overcome the drawbacks of conventional mechanism while maintaining the simple shape of the wheel, a modified Geneva mechanism in which the input radius is variable is considered. In the modified mechanism shown in Fig. 2, the input pin P is mounted on a follower link (A) which ‘slides’ relative to the input disk, while another roller on the follower link is engaged with a fixed groove-cam (C). As the input disk rotates, r1 is adjusted according to the shape of the curve that is ‘programmed’ into the cam. Theabove-mentioned disadvantages could be avoided and the kinematic performance of the mechanism optimized by adopting a carefully designed ‘adjustment strategy’ for r1. To formulate the problem, the input pin and the wheel groove are considered in an intermediate engaged position (Fig. 1(b)).

sec.title: 3 THE PROPOSED OPTIMIZATION METHOD
sec.p: The multiple design variables introduced in the formulation of the optimization problem form a huge search space in RN, where N is the number of polynomial coefficients. Population-based evolutionary algorithms (EAs) are commonly employed to handle problems of similar complexity. The most widely adopted EA is believed to be the GAs.

GAs mimic the evolutionary processes of natural selection and reproduction through the application of special genetic operators to populations of coded potential solutions. A set of artificial chromosomes forms a population, where each chromosome is evaluated and ranked based on its fitness, which is basically a measure of how good the solution is. The initial population of chromosomes is evolved into typically fitter populations using such genetic operators as reproduction, cross-over, and mutation. Various reproduction schemes implement the Survival of the Fittest paradigm where more promising solutions receive higher chances of contributing to the production of following generations. Cross-over encourages the exploitation of good genes in the construction of future chromosomes, whereas mutation enables the algorithm to explore new areas of the search space.

The power of GAs lies in their ability to venture into unprecedented areas of the solution space and fuse the knowledge from previously visited areas at the same time to come up with new, potentially fitter solutions [21].

Nonetheless, the performance of traditional GAs in function domains with abrupt variations is anything but perfect. The authors’ numerous experiments with solution spaces wherein local/global minima lie within deep narrow valleys have shown that the algorithm, more often than not, misses the minimum and settles for sub-optimal solutions, unless of course it is given indefinite time, sometimes even more than what an exhaustive search would require.

To further investigate this problem, an experiment was designed in which the traditional GA was applied to the above problem. The results of 100 runs showed that in nearly 70 instances, the algorithm failed to significantly improve ϕ··max values, an obvious drawback which could only be attributed to GA’s inability to perform a fine local search in the neighbourhood of promising points.

This experiment suggests that the incorporation of a local search into the traditional GA could possibly resolve this problem. This will be further discussed in Section 4. However, a decision has to be made as ‘when’ and ‘where’ to conduct the local search. Searching the neighbourhoods of all individuals in every generation would be neither necessary nor computationally justifiable. Early generations, on the other hand, are less likely to contain too many individuals in the immediate vicinity of the global minimum (minima), whereas later generations with fitter solutions have expectedly focused on a limited number of promising ‘patches’, making it feasible for them to be more closely examined. The local search mechanism should therefore be able to adapt itself to the conditions of this dynamic situation.

In a previous publication [22], the authors proposed a hybrid GA with a built-in adaptive local search (ALS). The hybridization was shown to significantly improve the performance of the traditional GA, especially in highly multimodal search spaces similar to the one being studied here. A brief introduction of the local search algorithm is presented in the following section.

sec.title: 3.1 ALS algorithm
sec.p: In the proposed hybrid algorithm, the search for optimal solution(s) begins according to the traditional GA. A random initial population of candidate solutions is generated and evolved through consecutive generations.

Once the algorithm slows down on improving the average fitness of the population, the local search algorithm is activated. This is set to happen every time the cumulative change in the value of the population’s average fitness from q consecutive generations falls below the normalized fitness range of the qth generation. In this study, q was set to N, the number of design variables (13) (14)
As long as this condition holds, the local search is repeated every TLS generations.

It could be seen that the frequency of the local search increases as the population converges to some point in the function space, which is an obvious boost to the exploitation power of GA. It is also seen that in the early stages of the search, the local search is virtually called off to allow the algorithm to explore the solution space and spot promising areas.

The local search is performed around a subpopulation of elite solutions. Each time ALS is about to be called, individuals are sorted by their fitnesses and as many as Cel(=Npop/10) top individuals are marked for local search (Pi, i = 1 to Cel). A neighbourhood is defined for each individual by a vector of neighbourhood radii Ri = {Ri1, Ri2, … , Rin}, where Ri ∈ \Rn contains m (m ≤ n) non-zero components; meaning that it is not necessary for the search to take place in all dimensions of the variable space. The kth element of the neighbourhood radii vector is set equal to the minimum absolute difference between the kth element of the individual and that of other marked points, that is (15)
The number of directions in which the search is conducted (m) is set equal to N for functions of up to five variables, and to integer (n/2+1) for problems with more variables.
In the next step, N trial points (Qj, j = 1 to n) are randomly generated in the neighbourhood of each marked individual (Pi) using the following formula
Qj = Pi + αj. Ri, j = 1 to n, αj randomly chosen in the [0, 1 − fq ave.fq max.] domain.

Each neighbouring point is evaluated and if it dominates (is fitter than) the original point, it replaces the original point and the local search is called off for this individual. If none of the n neighbouring points dominates the original point, Pi remains unchanged.

The procedure is repeated for all marked individuals and the control is then handed back to GA to check the termination criterion and possibly move on to the next generation. In this study, the search was set to terminate once fave.fmax. exceeded 0.95 or the number of generations equalled 10 000, whichever came first. The 11 real-valued coefficients of the polynomial formed the chromosomes. The population size was set to 20 and a fitness-proportionate roulette wheel selection scheme was adopted. In the reproduction phase, a gene-preserving scattered cross-over scheme with a randomly generated mask vector of zeros and ones and a fraction of 0.8 along with a uniform mutation scheme with a probability of 0.02 were used.

sec.p:
The hybrid optimization algorithm outlined above was used to obtain the optimal shape of the groove-cam. Figure 5 shows the convergence history from a typical run of the algorithm for a four-slot wheel. Fig. 5

Figures 6 and 7 show the resulting velocity and acceleration curves for the wheel, respectively, compared with those of traditional Geneva mechanism. The results are presented here for a low number of slots (three, four, five, and six) for which the problems of high velocity and acceleration are more pronounced. The output velocity and acceleration are normalized for comparison purposes, using the input angular velocity. In these figures, the horizontal axis T = 1 − θ/(π/2 − π/n) represents the normalized input motion, varying in the interval [0,2]. Due to symmetry, only the first half is plotted. Fig. 6

As it could be seen from these curves, the maximum acceleration is noticeably reduced from that of the ordinary mechanism, while the problem of discontinuity at the beginning and end of motion is eliminated. In most cases, the maximum angular velocity is decreased (Fig. 6(a) to (c)), resulting ingreater output torques at the cost of a minimalincrease in the value of the angular velocity (Fig. 6(d)).

The hybridization of GA with an ALS algorithm could be further justified by the fact that the objective function, ϕ··max, is so sensitive to variations of the design variables that in some cases a mere 4 per cent change in one of the polynomial coefficients would change the value of ϕ··max by about 17 per cent. For instance, in the typical case of an order 10 polynomial, the coefficient vector [0.707, 0.002, 0.218, −1.030, 0.835, 0.087, 0.705, −0.733, −0.903, 0.769, 0.009] for the input polynomial results inϕ··max = 3.64, whereas changing the 4th coefficient from 0.835 to 0.800 (a 4.19 per cent reduction) would change the value of ϕ··max to 4.28 (a 17.6 per cent reduction). The extensive experiments carried out in this study showed that the classical GA would easily overlook this sensitivity and would often converge to an inferior solution.

Table 1 compares the maximum acceleration from a traditional Geneva mechanism, an optimized design, and a number of designs reported in the literature. It could be seen that the optimization has resulted in a 40.6 per cent reduction in the maximum acceleration compared to the conventional Geneva mechanism and a 5.6 per cent and 50.6 per cent reduction compared to the results reported in references [10, 14] for a four-slot wheel and in reference [4] for a five-slot one. sec.title: 5 SUMMARY
sec.p: Acknowledging the practically significant drawbacks of the traditional Geneva mechanism, an efficient alternative variety of the mechanism was presented and optimized. Using a fixed groove cam to control the radius of action of the driving pin, the discontinuity of the wheel acceleration was avoided and its maximum velocity and acceleration were reduced. An experimentally ordered polynomial was adopted as the displacement function of the cam in the interval of engagement of driver and wheel. Optimal values of the polynomial coefficients were obtained by minimizing the maximum acceleration of the Geneva wheel subject to the constraints of zero velocity and zero acceleration for the pin at the beginning and end of its motion. To do this, the equations of motion were derived using a variable radius for the driving pin instead of the constant radius of the conventional design. Because of the highly multimodal nature of the solution space and its sensitivity to the variations of design parameters that would render classical optimization algorithms rather inefficient, a hybrid GA with an ALS was employed to obtain the optimal polynomial coefficients.

The proposed approach was used to design Geneva mechanisms with four, five, and six grooves. Comparing the results with those obtained by other methods showed that the proposed approach is capable of designing shock-free mechanisms with significantly reduced maximum angular velocity and acceleration of the Geneva wheel (over 40 per cent reduction in a typical application). It was concluded that the improved performance of the proposed design would well justify the need for an extra groove-cam, especially in precision applications where high acceleration values and large variations in their values are undesirable.
